sn47.14:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Vajjīs near Ukkacelā on the bank of the Ganges river, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants. It was not long after Sāriputta and Moggallāna had become finally extinguished.
sn47.14:4.2: Now, at that time the Buddha was sitting in the open, surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks.
sn47.14:5.1: Then the Buddha looked around the Saṅgha of monks, who were silent. He addressed them:
sn47.14:5.2: “Mendicants, this assembly seems empty to me now that Sāriputta and Moggallāna have become finally extinguished.
sn47.14:5.3: When Sāriputta and Moggallāna were alive, my assembly was never empty; I had no concern for any region where they stayed.
sn47.14:5.4: All the perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas of the past had such a pair of chief disciples,
sn47.14:5.5: as Sāriputta and Moggallāna were to me.
sn47.14:5.6: All the perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas of the future will have such a pair of chief disciples,
sn47.14:5.7: as Sāriputta and Moggallāna were to me.
sn47.14:5.8: It’s an incredible and amazing quality of such disciples
sn47.14:5.9: that they fulfill the Teacher’s instructions and follow his advice. And they’re liked and approved, respected and admired by the four assemblies.
sn47.14:5.10: And it’s an incredible and amazing quality of the Realized One
sn47.14:5.11: that when such a pair of disciples becomes finally extinguished he does not sorrow or cry.
sn47.14:5.12: How could it we ever have it that
sn47.14:5.13: what is born, created, conditioned, and liable to fall apart should not fall apart?
sn47.14:5.15: Suppose there was a large tree standing with heartwood, and the largest branch fell off.
sn47.14:5.16: In the same way, in the great Saṅgha that stands with heartwood, Sāriputta and Moggallāna have become finally extinguished.
sn47.14:5.17: How could it we ever have it that
sn47.14:5.18: what is born, created, conditioned, and liable to fall apart should not fall apart?
sn47.14:5.20: So mendicants, be your own island, your own refuge, with no other refuge. Let the teaching be your island and your refuge, with no other refuge.
sn47.14:6.1: And how does a mendicant do this?
sn47.14:6.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.14:6.3: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.14:6.5: principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.14:6.6: That’s how a mendicant is their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge. That’s how the teaching is their island and their refuge, with no other refuge.
sn47.14:6.7: Whether now or after I have passed, any mendicant who lives as their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge; with the teaching as their island and their refuge, with no other refuge:
sn47.14:6.8: they will be the best of those who want to train.”
